title: Before 1 November 2019, will Judy Shelton and/or Christopher Waller be confirmed by the Senate for the Federal Reserve Board?
possible_answers: Yes, the Senate will confirm both
No, the Senate will confirm neither
correct_answer: No, the Senate will confirm neither
preds: Before 1 November 2019, will Judy Shelton and/or Christopher Waller be confirmed by the Senate for the Federal Reserve Board?
We have a Senate?   Cool.  When will they come out from under their desks and start to do things?
Moving the last three points to no because, these confirmations take time and there's less than two weeks left.

I checked back with the Senate Banking calendar - no nomination hearings on calendar through October.
Drilling down - I  still don't find a formal nomination for either.
I did find 5 others were nominated for various positions since the July 3rd announcement, and presently in queue.
Looks like Shelton/Waller were merely floated.
Waller could still get jammed through if WH pushed it.

https://wkzo.com/news/articles/2019/oct/02/outlier-influencer-feds-bullard-catches-trumps-eye/943055/ " . . . economist Judy Shelton and Bullard's research director Christopher Waller, have yet to be formally nominated."

1 of Trump's picks was confirmed. That proves he has the Senate votes to get his picks confirmed. But only 29 days to do it in. Time
pressure is huge on this question. Michelle Bowman Confirmed for Full Fed Board Term
https://www.marketwatch.com/story/senate-confirms-bowman-to-14-year-term-on-feds-board-2019-09-12
Starting to look like it won't happen, or it would already have been done.

https://moneymorning.com/2019/09/23/if-you-think-the-fed-is-bananas-now-just-you-wait/ On July 2, 2019, President Trump tweeted, "I am pleased to announce that it is my intention to nominate Judy Shelton, Ph. D., U.S. Executive Dir, European Bank of Reconstruction & Development to be on the board of the Federal Reserve…." . . .  he still hasn't formally nominated her;

I have searched high & low for information about the nomination of these 2 people.  All I can find is references to DJT's intent to nominate them. I find no mention of either of them here:
https://www.banking.senate.gov/legislative-calendar/nominations?PageNum_rs=1& And I find no  confirmation hearings on the calendar of the senate banking committee here:
https://www.banking.senate.gov/hearings?mode=calendar @ddorsey found discussion of Shelton's nomination in a talk show, but the thrust of the discussion was about her thinking as an economist, not about the nuts & bolts of her nomination.  In that discussion, the point was made that both of these candidates have been confirmed once (to other positions).   However, in the articles in which DJT's intention to nominate them is discussed, Shelton's love of gold was mentioned as a possible red light for at least one of the Republicans on the Senate Banking Committee.   Perhaps this is the source of the low forecasts here on her confirmation. Am I missing something???    I'm pinging @Raahul_Kumar because he is an awesome researcher who manages to dig up stuff nobody else finds.

The two open seats are part of the FOMC's  Board of Governors.  The are 7 Governors, appointed to 14 year terms by the President of the US.  In addition to the 7 governors, there are also 5 Federal Reserve appointments to fill out the 12 member FOMC.
It is common to see the governors positions left empty, as it increses the influence of the US banks, who are limited to 5 seats  For example, currently there are 5 bank representatives and 5 Presidential appointed governors.  Depending on whether Congress approves Presidential nominees, or leaves the positions open, is an indication of Congressional preference for a. banking or b. Presidential influence on the FOMC.

thanks to @SuretyGuy
https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/903855 I can't find any information as to if either of them has actually even been nominated yet.

We're out of time on the Senate calendar.
These things usually go on for 4 months.
We're down to 15 legislative days in Sep and 13 days in Oct.
As of today - Senate Banking Committee has not set up any time for Fed nominee hearings  - and I've not found that a formal nomination has ever been sent to the Majority Leader for him to make referral to Senate Banking. So I can't see how confirmation is possible.
The senators will go along with Trump’s selections.

Trump has yet to officially nominate either Christopher Waller or Judy Shelton to the Board of Governors in spite of having tweeted his intentions to do so. Recent experience has shown that delays in formally putting the names to the Senate and starting the process is a fairly strong indication that these will not come to fruition, or that the names in question will withdraw rather than deal with a lengthy and/or contentious confirmation. Shelton is probably not a viable nomination. Waller, on the other hand, could make it through, although he would face a tough battle in maintaining his independence as a monetary policymaker in the face of Trump’s undisguised desire for a loyalist on the Board of Governors. 
https://whetstoneanalysis.com/2019/08/21/comment-dissents-in-the-fomc-vote-are-likely-to-continue-maybe-into-2020/
Waller has advocated for average inflation targeting , which would be in line with Republican desires for more stimulative monetary policy ahead of the 2020 election.

The Senate has started to push back on candidates  - and the White House has pulled others back. As long as he has a pliant Fed - Trump doesn't care who it is - or who it is not. 
My reading of Shelton is as a gold bug - and her prior positions seem at odd relative to her positions today. 
Waller is like a pitch down the middle of the plate.

Trump made a prior attempt to fill the seats: He nominated the economists Marvin Goodfriend and Nellie Liang in 2017 and 2018, respectively, but the Republican-controlled Senate would not confirm either of them.
http://nymag.com/intelligencer/2019/07/theres-no-need-for-the-senate-to-confirm-anyone-to-the-fed.html Given his prior failure the chances of them both being confirmed are negligible, in spite of the Republicans holding control of the Senate.
I'd be higher on "both" if I had any idea who Judy Shelton or Christopher Waller are :)
The current spat between the President and Powell and the movements in interest rates show the problem of potentially 'packing' the FRB. You don't need to be  a Democrat to find that disturbing.
Judy Shelton seems to be getting a lot of skepticism from the Senate, while Chris Waller is a more conventional choice.
Because I just signed on to this site and it is the first question that came up. I probably should check out the training page. Plus, I think that Waller has a better shot than Shelton.

I am on the leadership board for predicting the right price of gold I went against the crowd and won the federal reserve guy should leave or be sacked and do the honourable thing leave even though he has a four year contract and refuses not a man with integrity he must of been incompetent not listening to me imagine all that money I could of made them
Updating based on the crowd and attempting to add in some more resolution than they have.
As @1MM1 pointed out, the average time to confirm nominees to be confirmed is 4.9 months. With the senate in recess for most of August, this confirmation timeless is way too tight.

They will confirm Christopher Waller first because he is an advocate of low interest rates which will appeal across party lines.  Judy Shelton is a more challenging confirmation but I expect that a Republican led Senate will likely confirm both.

Governor	                       |Nominated	| Confirmed by Senate|  Time to confirm(month)|	Difference from Average(month)|
Michelle W. Bowman	       |  Apr-18	| Nov-18	                 |            7.1	                        |        2.3(rounding)
Lael Brainard	               |  1/10/2014	|6/12/2014		         |             5.1	                        |        0.3
Jerome Powell (2nd time)  |  Jan-14	        | Jun-14		                 |             5.0	                        |        0.2
Jerome Powell	               |  27-Dec-11	| 17-May-12		         |             4.7	                        |       -0.1
Richard H. Clarida	       |  24-Apr-18	| 28-Aug-18		         |             4.2	                        |       -0.6
Randal K. Quarles	       |  10-Jul-17	|  5-Oct-17		         |             2.9	                        |       -2.0
Average	time to confirm			                                                                4.9	 Let's make a rough guess that distribution of "times to confirm" is normal and 86.6%
(which roughly corresponds to 1 in 7 approximate expected frequency outside range, and we have 6 observations) 
of the observations are in the  4.9 +/- 2.3 interval [2.6 ; 7.2].  Then standard deviation is 1.53.(1.5 * st.dev = 2.3 )
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/68%E2%80%9395%E2%80%9399.7_rule Shelton and Waller will be likely nominated after the recess. Then the Senate will have only 2 month to confirm them before 1 November 2019. 2 month is 2.9 month from the average time to confirm(4.9) , which is around 1.86 standard deviations from the average. 
Then probability of either of the nominees be confirmed solely based on the base rate is around 3%.
 (the values within 1.86 standard deviations of the mean account for about 94% of the set, then the values outside of  1.86 standard deviations of the mean account for around 6% and we need to take the values from only the left tail). Shelton is not a trained economist and has some controversial opinions(she advocates return to the gold standard). It seems very unlikely for the Senate to confirm her in such a time frame.  Waller, in my opinion, has much higher chances to be confirmed (no controversial views, required experience,  generally good comments from senators about his appointment).  I raise to 6% probability of Waller be confirmed in such a tight time frame.

In general, I see Waller being confirmed and Shelton withdrawing her nomination because the Senate will not move her forward.
Recent appointments can take 3 months to six months https://www.washingtonpost.com/graphics/politics/trump-administration-appointee-tracker/database/?utm_term=.6bf86b8a5def
But this is a tight 3-month window - actually, a two month window, given the Senate is in recess in August.
If anyone could breeze through like he's 'with the band" - it's Waller b/c he already is "with the band" - he presently works at the St Louis Fed under James Bullard, and his views are well known, and he's fashionably dovish.

Shelton faces an uphill battle, while Waller is a more traditional candidate. Due to the controversy over Cain and Moore. It's possible they'll appoint Waller and pass on Shelton, or maybe do them both, but seems very unlikely Shelton will be appointed and Waller passed over. https://www.marketwatch.com/story/trumps-two-fed-picks-facing-different-odds-at-winning-senate-approval-2019-07-03

The current board members had 2-6 months between nomination and confirmation (see their Wikipedia articles cited below). Neither candidate has been officially nominated, and summer recess is around the corner as pointed out by @Raisinville
https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/885413
I think Waller will be confirmed, but maybe not in timeframe of the question. Shelton is a more controversial candidate, so forecasting a low probability for her confirmation in addition to the timing issue.

Neither Waller nor Shelton has been nominated yet.  The Senate must confirm the nominees, the August Senate recess starts the first week of August.  There may be a delay in the process. Waller should be confirmed based on merit.  Confirmed by Nov. 1 is less certain. Suspect the changing views of Shelton will be a difficult sell.  However, in a post-Trump FEderal Reserve, Shelton's views are standard conservative positions.  Willingness to support the current objectives might also be a long term conservative benefit.  Might have a difficult confirmation process. Waller & Bullard, StL FED, both are currently viewed as doves, and likely to be supportive of Trump's loose monetary policy objectives (at least in the short term).  Highly credible candidates from the StLouis FED, which, prior to the financial crisis was more aligned with more hawkish policies.
